**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the children.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.proposition: Courts routinely hold that parenting schedules must accommodate the realities of a parent’s ability to adequately supervise and care for their children.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns removal of children from the Commonwealth in a joint physical custody arrangement and applies a best-interests-of-the-child standard. While it discusses how relocation can affect each parent’s ability to exercise custodial responsibilities and the children’s relationships with both parents, it does not articulate any general principle that parenting schedules must be structured around a parent’s ability to adequately supervise and care for the children. The focus is on relocation and best interests, not on routine adjustment of parenting schedules to parental caregiving realities.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.relevant_excerpt: “It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2.proposition: A parent’s failure to adequately care for children during parenting time has been grounds for modification.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2.support_reasoning: The case is a direct review of an initial custody determination between unmarried parents under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a modification proceeding based on changed circumstances. Nowhere does the opinion discuss modification standards, or treat a parent’s failure to adequately care for a child during parenting time as grounds to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order. The decision instead addresses allocation of initial custody under a best-interests analysis and the statutory factors concerning primary caregiver and stability.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 842 (2.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20…”}

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: A significant change in a parent’s employment and its impact on the care of children constitutes a material change in circumstances.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss modification of an existing custody order or what constitutes a “material change in circumstances.” Instead, it concerns an initial divorce and custody judgment and articulates the ‘real advantage’ standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth, focusing on the custodial parent’s reasons for relocation and the best interests of the children. While the wife’s employment prospects and economic situation are discussed, the case does not frame them as a material change in circumstances in the post-judgment modification sense described in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)….”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Courts have long recognized that stability is critical to the welfare of children and will place constraints on parenting schedules that disrupt children’s routines or lead to unsafe supervision.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on best interests of the children and rejects joint custody and more expansive visitation because it would be “injurious to the children” and an “invitation to continued warfare and conflict,” emphasizing minimizing disruption and fostering a healthy environment. The court specifically notes the importance of the primary caretaker relationship and the need to “minimize[] disruption,” which reflects concern for stability in the children’s routines and circumstances, though it does not explicitly frame this as ‘constraints on parenting schedules’ in modern terminology. Thus it provides moderate but not perfect support for the stated proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (20.proposition: The Plaintiff seeks a modification that is narrowly tailored to allow the Defendant to maintain a meaningful relationship with the Children while ensuring their safety and consistent care.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies a best‑interests analysis to a custody dispute and affirms an order that preserves the child’s relationship with both parents while prioritizing stability and safety. The court notes that the judge awarded primary physical custody to the parent more likely to meet the child’s needs and support the other parent’s role, and it describes a detailed visitation schedule designed to give the noncustodial parent meaningful, ongoing contact, conditioned on the child’s welfare. This aligns with a proposition that a modification should be narrowly tailored to maintain a meaningful relationship with the noncustodial parent while ensuring the children’s safety and consistent care.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (20.relevant_excerpt: Moreover, the judge found that Hunter was entirely supportive of Jill’s relationship with Rose and respects Rose’s role as Jill’s other parent as demonstrated by the fact that, during her parenting time, she has Jill telephone Rose every night to say good night, refers to Rose as “Mommy Miko,” and keeps a photograph of Rose in Jill’s bedroom. … The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week.
